items.synopsis: US Coast Guard authorities confirm the destruction of the missing Titan submersible,Â announcing a "debris field" was found near the Titanic wreck. Follow live.

title.children: Coast Guard says debris field points to 'catastrophic' loss of pressure in missing submersible

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In their statement released this morning confirming the deaths of Titan's five occupants, OceanGate called the passengers "true explorers." "We now believe that our CEO Stockton Rush, Shahzada Dawood and his son Suleman Dawood, Hamish Harding, and Paul-Henri Nargeolet, have sadly been lost." "These men were true explorers who shared a distinct spirit of adventure, and a deep passion for exploring and protecting the world's ocean."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: OceanGate calls passengers 'true explorers'

children.content: In their statement released this morning confirming the deaths of Titan's five occupants, OceanGate called the passengers "true explorers."
shared a distinct spirit of adventure
, and a deep passion for exploring and protecting the world's ocean."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan was at the Coast Guard press conference in Boston where the outcome of the search for the sub was announced. Officials in Boston had insisted as recently as yesterday that they were still hopeful of finding the five people onboard the submersible alive. With those hopes dashed, attention now turns to what comes next. Remotely operated vehicles (ROVs) will continue to search the area where the debris has been found, in an attempt to help investigators work out what might have gone wrong. But the Coast Guard could not say whether there was any chance of recovering any of the passengers' bodies. The size of the international press pack attending the Coast Guard's daily updates has grown substantially throughout the week, pointing to the global level of interest in the unfolding search operation. Sadly, it has not ended in the way rescuers or the families of those on board had been desperately wishing for.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Search to turn attention to investigating what went wrong

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Cameron, director of the Oscar-winning film Titanic, told ABC News Americahe finds the tragedy "astonishing and surreal." "I'm struck by the similarity of the Titanic disaster itself where the captain was repeatedly warned about ice ahead of his ship and yet he steamed into an ice field on a moonless night â and many people died as a result," he said. "It's a very similar tragedy where warnings went unheeded. "To take place at the same exact site with all the diving that's going on all around the worldâ¦ I think it's just astonishing and surreal. He says the diving community is small and that he had known French diver Paul-Henri Nargeolet for 25 years. "For him to die tragically in this way is almost impossible for me to process." Cameron has completed 33 deep sea dives to the historic wreck, saying he's "spent more time on the ship than the captain did." "I also designed and built a sub to go to the deepest place in the ocean, three times deeper than the Titanic, so I understand the engineering and safety problems associated with building this type of vehicle," he adds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Director James Cameron 'struck by the similarity' of the two Titanic disasters

children.content: James Cameron spoke to ABC America.
, director of the Oscar-winning film Titanic, told ABC News Americahe finds the tragedy "astonishing and surreal."

"I'm struck by the similarity of the Titanic disaster itself where the captain was repeatedly warned about ice ahead of his ship and yet he steamed into an ice field on a moonless night â and many people died as a result," he said.
"It's a very similar tragedy where warnings went unheeded.
"To take place at the same exact site with all the diving that's going on all around the worldâ¦ I think it's just astonishing and surreal.
He says the diving community is small and that he had known French diver
"For him to die tragically in this way is almost impossible for me to process."
Cameron has completed 33 deep sea dives to the historic wreck, saying he's "spent more time on the ship than the captain did."

"I also designed and built a sub to go to the deepest place in the ocean, three times deeper than the Titanic, so I understand the engineering and safety problems associated with building this type of vehicle," he adds.
